events.event_description: A full solar eclipse will temporarily disrupt 6.5 GW of utility-scale solar generation from Texas through Maine, with an additional 84.8 GW of capacity being partially affected across a larger area of the United States.
events.citation: On April 8, 2024, a full solar eclipse will briefly but fully obscure sunlight to utility-scale solar generation facilities from Texas through Maine with a combined 6.5 gigawatts (GW) of capacity. In addition, the eclipse will partially block sunlight to facilities with a combined 84.8 GW of capacity in an even larger swath of the United States around peak solar generating time.

events.event_description: U.S. battery storage capacity has increased significantly since the last solar eclipse, growing from 0.6 GW in 2017 to 15.4 GW currently.
events.citation: In the United States, we have 15.4 GW of battery storage. During the last solar eclipse, in 2017, only 0.6 GW of battery storage was operating in the United States.

events.event_description: U.S. utility-scale solar capacity reached 91 GW, representing 8% of total U.S. capacity, with nearly 100 GW of combined utility-scale and small-scale solar capacity added since 2017.
events.citation: Utility-scale solar capacity was 8% (91 GW) of total U.S. capacity at the end of 2023. Since then, however, the U.S. electricity portfolio has changed significantly; almost 100 GW of utility-scale and small-scale solar capacity has been added to the system.

events.event_description: The previous solar eclipse in 2017 had minimal impact on the U.S. power system, when solar was the fifth-leading energy source behind natural gas, coal, nuclear, and hydroelectric.
events.citation: The effect of the 2017 solar eclipse on the power system was minor. During the 2017 eclipse, solar generation was the fifth-leading energy source in the United States behind natural gas, coal, nuclear, and hydroelectric.
